case_name: Kanwal Lal v. Mst. Ram Rakhi

facts.text: This is Criminal Appeal No. 106 of 1961.

anchor.surface_text: Criminal Appeal No. 106 of 1961. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated May 11, 1961, of the Punjab High Court in Cr. R. No. 580 of 1961.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated May 11, 1961, of the Punjab High Court in Cr. R. No. 580 of 1961.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated May 11, 1961, of the Punjab High Court in Cr. R. No. 580 of 1961. Naunit Lal, for the appellant.

facts.text: Judgment of the Court delivered on September 28, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: 1962. September 28. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by AYYANGAR, J.-This is an appeal by special leave against the judgment of the High Court of Punjab

facts.text: Punjab High Court dismissed in limine a Criminal Revision filed against an appellate order of the Additional Sessions Judge, Ludhiana confirming the appellant's conviction and sentence.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by AYYANGAR, J.-This is an appeal by special leave against the judgment of the High Court of Punjab by which a Criminal Revision filed against an appellate order of the Additional Sessions judge, Ludhiana confirming the appellants conviction and sentence was dismissed in limine.

facts.text: Appellant prosecuted on a complaint filed by Mst. Ram Rakhi for offence of defamation under s. 500, I.P.C.

anchor.surface_text: The facts giving rise to the appeal lie in a very narrow compass. The appellant was prosecuted on a complaint filed by Mst. Ram Rakhi of the offence of defamation under s. 500, I.P.C.

facts.text: Appellant and Mst. Ram Rakhi were neighbours.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant and Mst. Ram Rakhi were neighbours. The defamatory matter was contained in a communication addressed by the appellant

facts.text: Appellant is a member of the police force.

anchor.surface_text: communication addressed by the appellant who is a member of the police force to the District Panchayat Officer, Ludhiana.

facts.text: Defamatory matter contained in a communication addressed by appellant to the District Panchayat Officer, Ludhiana.

anchor.surface_text: The defamatory matter was contained in a communication addressed by the appellant who is a member of the police force to the District Panchayat Officer, Ludhiana. In this application the appellant alleged

facts.text: Appellant alleged that complainant was a woman of loose character having illicit connection with goondas, paramours coming at nights, immoral activities reflected badly on locality.

anchor.surface_text: In this application the appellant alleged that the complainant was a woman of loose character who was having illicit connection with goondas, her paramours coming to her frequently at nights and that her immoral activities reflected badly on the locality in which the appellant lived.

facts.text: The matter was grossly defamatory of the complainant.

anchor.surface_text: There is no doubt that this was grossly defamatory of the complainant.

facts.text: Defence of appellant was that allegations were true and entitled to make application to Panchayat to get complainant out of locality.

anchor.surface_text: The defence of the appellant substantially was that in substance the allegations were true and that he was entitled to make this application to the Panchayat in order to seek the assistance of that body for getting the complainant out of the locality

facts.text: Appellant requested Panchayat of village Sanghol P. O. Sangho District Ludhiana to take action to end prostitution and vacate house of Shadi, father of complainant.

anchor.surface_text: It is therefore requested that the Panchayat of village Sanghol P. O. Sangho District Ludhiana may kindly be asked to take suitable action to end this prostitution and after getting the house in which Shadi father of the complainant, is residing at present, vacated from him.

facts.text: Learned Magistrate considered evidence on plea of justification and qualified privilege under exceptions 8 and 9 of s. 499 IPC, rejected defence, convicted appellant and sentenced to rigorous imprisonment for six months.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Magistrate considered a large volume of evidence that was led as regards the plea of justification as well as of the qualified privilege within exceptions 8 and 9 of s. 499, I.P.C., and rejecting the defence, convicted the appellant of the offence charged and sentenced him to undergo rigorous imprisonment for six months.

facts.text: Appellant filed appeal which was dismissed by Additional Sessions Judge Ludhiana.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant filed an appeal which was dismissed by the Additional Sessions judge

facts.text: Additional Sessions Judge concluded accused Kanwal Lal rightly convicted and sentenced, offence established, no mercy, used office to overawe complainant, first offence, youthful age.

anchor.surface_text: and he recorded I come to the conclusion that accused Kanwal Lal was rightly convicted and sentenced by the Trial Court. the offence against him is fully established. He deserves no mercy. He was employed in the office of the Inspector General Police, Punjab Chandigarh and he tried to use his office which he was holding simply to overawe the poor complainant and her parents, just to get the possession of his house from them. The quantum of sentence passed against the accused appears to be correct in view of his first offence and youthful age.

facts.text: Accused Kanwal Lal employed in office of Inspector General Police, Punjab Chandigarh.

anchor.surface_text: He was employed in the office of the Inspector General Police, Punjab Chandigarh and he tried to use his office

facts.text: Revision against Additional Sessions Judge's judgment dismissed in limine by High Court.

anchor.surface_text: It was the revision filed against this judgment that was dismissed in limine by the High Court.

facts.text: No dispute about publication or published matter being defamatory falling within s. 499 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: There being no dispute about the publication or of the published matter being defamatory being of a character falling within s. 499, I.P.C.,

Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated May 11, 1961, of the Punjab High Court in Cr. R. No. 580 of 1961. Naunit Lal, for the appellant.
The appellant was prosecuted on a complaint filed by Mst. Ram Rakhi of the offence of defamation under s. 500, I.P.C.
under s. 500, I.P.C. The appellant and Mst. Ram Rakhi were neighbours. The defamatory matter was contained in a communication addressed by the appellant

anchor.surface_text: the only argument that was addressed before us was based upon the case falling within Exceptions 8 and 9 to S. 499, I.P.C. Exception 8 runs in these terms It is no defamation to prefer in good faith an accusation against any person to any of those who have lawful authority over that person with respect to the subject-matter of accusation.

concepts.interpretation: Requires proof that the person to whom complaint made had lawful authority over the person complained against in respect of subject-matter; rejected because Panchayat lacked jurisdiction over prostitution or public nuisance involving public servant.

anchor.surface_text: in view of the clear provisions of the Punjab Gram Panchayat Act, 1952, under which statute alone Panchayats have jurisdiction.

issues.text: Whether the case falls within Exception 8 to Section 499, I.P.C.?

anchor.surface_text: the only argument that was addressed before us was based upon the case falling within Exceptions 8 and 9 to S. 499, I.P.C. Exception 8 runs in these terms It is no defamation to prefer in good faith an accusation against any person to any of those who have lawful authority over that person with respect to the subject-matter of accusation.

issues.text: Whether the case falls within Exception 9 to Section 499, I.P.C.?

anchor.surface_text: Nor is there more substance in the invocation of the 9th exception. That exception runs It is no defamation to make an imputation on the character of another provided that the imputation be made in good faith for the protection of the interest of the person making it, or of any other person, or of the public good.

issues.text: Whether the Gram Panchayat had lawful authority or jurisdiction over the subject-matter of the accusation (prostitution or public nuisance)?

anchor.surface_text: In order to establish a defence under this exception the accused would have to prove that the person to whom the complaint was made had lawful authority over the person complained against, in respect of the subject-matter of the accusation. If the District Panchayat Officer or the Panchayat had such lawful authority, the last paragraph of the offending communication would have justified such a plea. But there is no basis at all for this argument in view of the clear provisions of the Punjab Gram Panchayat Act, 1952, under which statute alone Panchayats have jurisdiction.

arguments.claim: District Panchayat Officer or Panchayat had no lawful authority over subject-matter of accusation under Exception 8

anchor.surface_text: In order to establish a defence under this exception the accused would have to prove that the person to whom the complaint was made had lawful authority over the person complained against, in respect of the subject-matter of the accusation. If the District Panchayat Officer or the Panchayat had such lawful authority, the last paragraph of the offending communication would have justified such a plea. But there is no basis at all for this argument

arguments.claim: Panchayat criminal jurisdiction confined to offences in Schedule IA per s.38 Punjab Gram Panchayat Act; prostitution/bawdy house not included

anchor.surface_text: in view of the clear provisions of the Punjab Gram Panchayat Act, 1952, under which statute alone Panchayats have jurisdiction. Chapter IV of that Act deals with the Criminal jurisdiction of the Panchayat. Section 38 with which that Chapter opens enacts The criminal jurisdiction of a Gram Panchayat shall be confined to the trial of offences specified in Schedule IA. Prostitution is no an offence under the Indian Penal Code and the keeping of a disorderly or bawdy house is no an offence within Schedule 1 A

arguments.claim: Panchayat barred from cognizance of IPC offence involving public servant per s.42 Punjab Gram Panchayat Act

anchor.surface_text: to which offences alone the criminal jurisdiction of Panchayats extends. If this were no sufficient to negative any defence based upon Exception 8, reference may be made to s. 42 of the Gram Panchayat Act which by its 1st sub-section enacts Subject to the provisions of sub.s.  3 no panchayat shall take cognizance of any offence under the Indian Penal Code, 1860

arguments.claim: Even if complaint of public nuisance, excluded from Panchayat jurisdiction as appellant public servant

anchor.surface_text: in which either the complainant or the accused is a public servant. So even if the complaint should be taken to be a complaint of a public- nuisance it was doubly excluded from the jurisdiction of the Panchayat since the appellant was a public servant. The defence based on Exception 8 must therefore fail.

arguments.claim: Exception 9 requires imputation made to person with common/corresponding interest or duty

anchor.surface_text: Even if good faith be taken to have been established, the imputation has to be made for the protection of the interest of the person making it. ... In other words, besides the bona fides of the person making the imputation, the person to whom the imputation is conveyed must have a common interest with the person making it which is served by the communication.

arguments.claim: Exception 9 reproduces principle in Harrison v. Bush requiring corresponding interest or duty

anchor.surface_text: This exception merely reproduces the principle laid down by Lord Campbell, C. J., in Harrison v. Bush. A communication made bona fide upon any subject matter in which the party communicating has an interest, or in reference to which he has a duty, is privileged, if made to a person having a corresponding interest or duty

arguments.claim: Communication does not satisfy test for Exception 9

anchor.surface_text: although it contain criminatory matter which, without this privilege, would be slanderous and actionable. The point of difference between exceptions, 8 and 9 is that whereas in the former the person to whom the complaint is made must have lawful authority to deal with the subject matter of the complaint and take proceedings against that person, there is no such requirement in exception 9 where it is sufficient if a communication is made to a person for the protection of ones own interest in which the other also has an interest. ... It cannot be seriously suggested that the communication in question satisfies this test.

holdings.text: The defence based on Exception 8 must therefore fail.

anchor.surface_text: in which either the complainant or the accused is a public servant. So even if the complaint should be taken to be a complaint of a public- nuisance it was doubly excluded from the jurisdiction of the Panchayat since the appellant was a public servant. The defence based on Exception 8 must therefore fail.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Panchayat lacked lawful authority over subject-matter because prostitution/bawdy house not in Schedule IA (s.38) and barred for public servant involvement (s.42 Punjab Gram Panchayat Act); even as public nuisance excluded.

holdings.text: Prostitution is no an offence under the Indian Penal Code and the keeping of a disorderly or bawdy house is no an offence within Schedule 1 A to which offences alone the criminal jurisdiction of Panchayats extends.

anchor.surface_text: confined to the trial of offences specified in Schedule IA. Prostitution is no an offence under the Indian Penal Code and the keeping of a disorderly or bawdy house is no an offence within Schedule 1 A to which offences alone the criminal jurisdiction of Panchayats extends. If this were no sufficient to negative any defence based upon Exception 8,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct textual application of s.38 Punjab Gram Panchayat Act limiting jurisdiction to listed offences; prostitution and bawdy house excluded.

holdings.text: no panchayat shall take cognizance of any offence under the Indian Penal Code, 1860 in which either the complainant or the accused is a public servant.

anchor.surface_text: reference may be made to s. 42 of the Gram Panchayat Act which by its 1st sub-section enacts Subject to the provisions of sub.s.  3 no panchayat shall take cognizance of any offence under the Indian Penal Code, 1860 in which either the complainant or the accused is a public servant. So even if the complaint should be taken to be a complaint of a public-

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applied s.42(1) barring Panchayat cognizance where public servant (appellant) involved, doubly excluding jurisdiction.

holdings.text: It cannot be seriously suggested that the communication in question satisfies this test.

anchor.surface_text: where it is sufficient if a communication is made to a person for the protection of ones own interest in which the other also has an interest. This is clearly brought out by the illustra- tions to the exception. It cannot be seriously suggested that the communication in question satisfies this test.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Exception 9 requires recipient to have corresponding/common interest with maker (per text, illustrations, Harrison v. Bush); District Panchayat Officer lacked such interest.

holdings.text: besides the bona fides of the person making the imputation, the person to whom the imputation is conveyed must have a common interest with the person making it which is served by the communication.

anchor.surface_text: That is certainly no the meaning of the exception. It posits that the person to whom the communication is made has an interest in protecting the person making the accusation. In other words, besides the bona fides of the person making the imputation, the person to whom the imputation is conveyed must have a common interest with the person making it which is served by the communication.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Interpretive holding on Exception 9: good faith insufficient alone; requires shared interest between maker and recipient, reproducing Harrison v. Bush principle.

holdings.text: The appellant was therefore properly convicted of the offence

anchor.surface_text: It cannot be seriously suggested that the communication in question satisfies this test. The appellant was therefore properly convicted of the offence and nothing was said about the sentence.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Defences under Exceptions 8 and 9 rejected; defamation under s.499/500 IPC established as admitted, defences fail.

precedents.citation: Harrison v. Bush  1   1855  5 E. B. 344, 348 119 E. R. 509

anchor.surface_text: Harrison v. Bush  1 . A companymunication made bona fide upon any subject matter in which the party companymunicating  1   1855  5 E. B. 344, 348 119 E. R. 509, has an interest, or in reference to which he has a duty, is privileged, if made to a person having a company

precedents.cited_proposition: A communication made bona fide upon any subject matter in which the party communicating has an interest, or in reference to which he has a duty, is privileged, if made to a person having a corresponding interest or duty, although it contains criminatory matter which, without this privilege, would be slanderous and actionable.
precedents.cited_holding: A communication made bona fide upon any subject matter in which the party communicating has an interest, or in reference to which he has a duty, is privileged, if made to a person having a corresponding interest or duty, although it contains criminatory matter which, without this privilege, would be slanderous and actionable.

anchor.surface_text: The defence based on Exception 8 must therefore fail. Nor is there more substance in the invocation of the 9th exception. That exception runs It is number defamation to make an imputation on the character of another provided that the imputation be made in good faith for the protection of the interest of the person making it, or of any other person, or of the public good.

outcome.relief_summary: Defences under Exceptions 8 and 9 to s. 499 I.P.C. rejected; appellant properly convicted of defamation under s. 500 I.P.C.; no interference with conviction or sentence

anchor.surface_text: That is certainly no the meaning of the exception. It posits that the person to whom the communication is made has an interest in protecting the person making the accusation. In other words, besides the bona fides of the person making the imputation, the person to whom the imputation is conveyed must have a common interest with the person making it which is served by the communication.
